So what falls into the heart [qalb], the imagination [khayal] hastens to it and imitates it with a resembling form, and the imagined things [al-mutakhayyilat] are more firmly established in memory than others, so the imagination [khayal] remains in the memory. Indeed, continuous reflection [fikr] upon Allah, the Exalted, His attributes and His actions is not attained except by bidding farewell to the world [dunya] and its desires, and being content with it only to the extent of sufficiency and necessity. And this is not perfected except by immersing the times of night and day in the duties of remembrance [adhkar] and reflection [afkar]. And the soul [nafs], due to what it is created upon of weariness and boredom, does not persevere with a single mode of the means that assist in remembrance [dhikr] and reflection [fikr]. Rather, if it is returned to one pattern, it displays boredom and a sense of burden. And indeed, Allah, the Exalted, does not tire until you tire. So from the necessity of gentleness with it is that it is refreshed by shifting from one mode to another and from one type to another according to each time, so that its pleasure [ladhdha] is increased by the transition, its desire [raghba] is magnified by the pleasure, and its constancy [mawazabata] endures by the endurance of the desire. Therefore, the litanies [awrad] are divided into different divisions. And remembrance [dhikr] and reflection [fikr] should encompass all times or most of them. For the soul [nafs] is, by its nature, inclined to the pleasures of the world [dunya]. If the servant spends half his times on the arrangements of the world [dunya] and its permissible desires, for example, and the other half on acts of worship, the side of inclination to the world [dunya] is weighted, because it agrees with the innate nature [tab'], since the time would be equal. So how can they be balanced when the innate nature [tab'] gives weight to one of them? Indeed, the soul [nafs], as it is created with weariness and boredom, cannot endure a single mode of the means that aid in remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr]. Rather, if it is returned to one pattern, it displays boredom and a sense of burden. And indeed, Allah the Exalted does not weary until you weary. Thus, from the necessity of gentleness with it is that you refresh it by shifting from one mode to another and from one type to another, according to each time, so that its pleasure [ladhdha] increases through the transition, its desire [raghba] is magnified through the pleasure, and its persistence [muwazaba] endures through the endurance of the desire. Therefore, the litanies [awrad] are divided into different divisions. And remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] should encompass all times or most of them. For the soul [nafs], by its nature, inclines toward the pleasures [ladha'at] of the world [dunya]. If the servant spends half his times on the arrangements and permissible desires of the world, for example, and the other half on acts of worship, the side of inclination to the world is weighted, as it agrees with the nature [tab'], since the time is equal. How can they be balanced when the nature [tab'] gives weight to one of them? For the outward [zahir] and inward [batin] cooperate in worldly matters, and the heart [qalb] becomes pure and single-minded in seeking them. As for being returned to acts of worship, it is forced, and the sincerity [ikhlas] and presence [hudur] of the heart [qalb] in it are not safe except at some times. Therefore, whoever wishes to enter Paradise without reckoning, let him immerse his times in obedience [ta'a]. If he mixes a righteous deed with an evil one, then his affair is perilous, but hope is not cut off, and pardon from the generosity of Allah is awaited. Perhaps Allah the Exalted will forgive him by His bounty [jud] and generosity [karam]. This is what has been unveiled to the observers by the light of insight [nur al-basira]. If you are not of its people, then look to the address of Allah the Exalted to His Messenger and take it by the light of faith [nur al-iman]. For Allah the Exalted has said: "So glorify [sabbih] at the ends [atraf] of the day." And this is the second end [taraf] intended by it. Therefore, it is recommended in this time specifically to glorify [tasbih] and seek forgiveness [istighfar], and all that we have mentioned in the first litany [wird]. For Allah the Exalted does not weary until you weary. So shifting between the litanies [awrad] at the ends [atraf] of the day refreshes the soul [nafs] and strengthens the continuity of remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr]. Thus, that becomes a path to watching over the times and filling them with litanies [awrad] on the path of continuity, just as the noble verses have clarified in the course of the sun, the moon, and the stars, so that you may know by them the measures of the times and occupy them with acts of obedience [ta'at] and trade for the Abode of the Hereafter [dar al-akhira].
